bodyenglish:
En stéréo, Caroline Martel et Tamara Vukov relatent les points saillants de Liberating Media, conférence-atelier sur les médias, la démocracie communautaire, le militantisme et les tactiques artistiques/politiques [détails sur les ateliers:  http://burn.ucsd.edu/~mai/NEWS/liberating.html]. Elles donnent aussi des recettes de culture jammingqu'elles y ont appris!

«Media does not refer to an institution, or a technological artifact,but rather an environment in which we all live. Media are the toolsby which we communicate amongst ourselves, each other, and the worldat large... The increasing corporate concentration of media declaresthe birth of a new regime of information mono cropping and mental colonization...We can break the homogeneity of the media monopoly by expressing ourselveswith our own media. Taking back our media means taking back our freedomand engaging in a revolution of many minds against a common enemy.»

Cette fin de semaine a été organisée en septembrepar le GRIP (Groupe de recherche d'intéret public) de l'UniversitéConcordia [http://alcor.concordia.ca/~qpirg], avec comme invités principaux des membres très allumés du Media Collective de Toronto et l'artisviste Beverly Naidus avec son diaporama sur l'art visuel engagé aux états-Unis. Étaient aussi présents notamment des gens de CKUT, de Videazimut et du Club Libertel.

On se rappelle avoir entendu parler, dans un ancien Femmes branchées, du groupe Guerilla Media qui avait fait un «coup» dans les grands magasins de Montréal lors de la Fête internationale des femmes pour protester contre l'exploitation de travailleuses dans l'industrie du textile? La fin de semaine Liberating Media a donné envie à des Montréalaises et Montréalais de continuer en ce sens et d'activer une sorte de MTL Media Collective... Avec des gens qui ont fait du théâre de rue pour faire connaîre les risques du missile américain Cassini, on participé au Plan G à Québec, on mené clandestinement une campagne de modification de pubs dans les toilettes d'universités, sont allés au Media & Democracy Congress II à New York, on lancé un zine...

Du culture jamming: des tactiques d'action sociale directes qui reposent sur des idées de détruire-créer-préserver pour donner des chocs culturels à visées politiques. Pour s'inspirer, lire «The Cuisines of Culture Jamming» d'AndrewBoyd, dans The Activist Cookbook publié par United fora Fair Economy [http://www.stw.org/] et dont une adaptation québécoise, «Techniques de sabotage culturel», a été faite pour un guide dedésobéissance civile.
[ www.colba.net/~spin/guide and  www.dsuper.net/~aboyeur/Guide.html]

On y explore des idées comme le détournement, le manifeste-agi, la contre-publicité, les théâres populaires, invisibles de rue, d'intervention et de l'opprimé, le journal vivant, la commotion, la provocation, le happening et les pirouettes médiatiques. Des suggestions pour le Studio XX? Permuter l'affiche publicitaire de l'émission américaine X Files sur la nouvelle chaîne Global pour annoncer plutôt l'émission radiophonique locale du Studio, XX Files...

bodyenglish:
My name is Tal Arbel. I am a doctoral student in the department of Electrical Engineering at McGill. A question that often comes up is how it is that I - being a woman of many interests - ended up in the sciences and more specifically how I came upon Engineering - a typically male-dominated field. I will tell you a bit about the motivating factors and influences that lead me to a career in science and technology.
First, I will tell you a bit about what I do. I am working in the area of Computer Vision in the Center for Intelligent Machines. The idea behind the center is to build smart machines like robots - capable of changing their behavior by sensing and interpreting their environment, making decisions and plans, and then carrying out those plans by moving around without human intervention. This might include getting a robot to pick up an object, move around an object, inspect it, etc. Computer Vision is a field that focuses on the problem of getting a computer to see and understand what it is seeing. The idea is to acquire visual data using a camera, a laser or others, to extract the interesting features from the image in order to get descriptions of the objects in the scene, to recognize these objects and to interpret the entire scene.
I am working on the problem of getting the robot to recognize objects. This entails placing an object in front of a camera, taking pictures or measuring how far the object is from a laser, and getting the computer to estimate the shape and size of the object. Then, the computer has to figure out which of the objects it has seen already it is looking at.
Personal Motivations:
My personal interest in a field such as computer vision has been primarily linked to the fact that it comprises many different fascinating areas. It involves collaborative efforts by researchers with very different interests, encouraging interdisciplinary activities which transcend the traditional departmental boundaries. These include scientific areas such as neurophysiology, psychology, mathematics, physics.
However, the field is also heavily influenced by other disciplines as well. Vision researchers ask many of the same questions asked by artists over time: How does lighting affect object shape? How does the appearance of objects change when viewed from different angles? An artist must understand these things in order to paint a realistic picture. A vision researcher must take them into account as well because sometimes we can only measure how bright the objects in the scene are and we need to infer shape from that little information. Also we need to get the computer to recognize the object even if it looks very different from different positions and with different lighting.
As well, philosophical questions arise. Vision addresses the issues of: How do we define learning, understanding, cognition, intelligence? It is not a field that simply involves manufacturing widgets, but it involves dreaming up and developing technology that makes you rethink every day processes that we take for granted. For example, when we try to get computers to understand what they are seeing, we must rethink what it means to learn new things. When we recognize objects that we have never seen before, what processes of cognition come into play? What is the difference between knowledge and intelligence? These are issues that we must think about if we wish to get a computer to think on its own.
The field of Artificial Intelligence thought it should be easy to make a computer think on its own. There was much hype when this field was first introduced. They thought it would be simple to show a computer a cup and have it understand what it was. After all, we do these things quite easily as humans. When they began to examine the task more closely, they realized, that mundane, daily acts that we take for granted are not trivial. When we tried to get a robot to pick up a cup off a table, we began to understand that knowing where the cup ends and where the table begins is not easy. How do you get the computer to understand how heavy the cup is by looking at it? How do we get it to estimate how slippery it might be? These things are obvious to us but it is hard to pinpoint what exactly it is that makes us understand these everyday tasks. As a result, there was great dissappointment in the field and people became less interested in the problem of artificial intelligence.
However, other disciplines came to the aid of computer vision. In studying how to get machines to see and perceive, researchers began examining how the most successful working visual system works - namely, the human visual system. Neurologists studying how the brain works were not able to tell us much about how the visual system works, as that part of the brain is relatively not understood. Thus, in order to be able to create an autonomous intelligent machine, computer vision researchers began working in collaboration with neurophysiologists and psychologists in trying to understand how we as humans acquire and process visual information. The goal, of course, was not to mimic human thought, but to understand it sufficiently to be able to borrow ideas for our own thinking machine. It was found that the human visual system is actually very sophisticated and thus building THE artificial vision machine became impossible. The result is that the field is focusing on understanding and solving more specific vision problems in the hopes of putting them together one day.
The fact that these inter-disciplinary connections such as these need to be made is what makes this area interesting.
In addition to the scientific aspect, the benefits of a career in research is that the process is creative. For some people, creativity manifests itself in drawing or painting. For others such as myself, it is through the computer. In either of these cases, one creates connections between ideas where none existed before. In addition, I believe that women in male-dominated areas have an advantage in that their perspective is slightly different than those of the men, providing fresh new insight in their solutions.
Personal Background:
So, having said what I do, how did I end up in this field? Engineering is not a discipline that society encourages women to enter. It is common to think that men are more naturally inclined towards the pure and applied sciences and that women are not only uninterested in such things, but that they are perhaps not naturally talented in math and physics. If such is that case, how is it that women such as myself ended up choosing a career in Engineering research and excelling at it at par with my male colleagues?
In my opinion, the primary influence for women who went on to pursue their interests in science came from the home. As is the case for most of my female colleagues, my father is an Engineer. As such, I was exposed to this career option quite early, learning what it is that he does and deciding if it interested me. I was encouraged to ask questions and my father - excited to have someone to share his interests with - spoke freely of his work and explained alot to me. My parents, taking note of my natural interest and curiosity in how things worked, bought me many books and even a computer and played math games with me at a young age. Although I had a normal childhood and even played with dolls, no one ever told me that these interests were restricted for "boys" and thus were off limits. Only as an adult, did I realize how forward-thinking my parents were.
In addition to my home life, I was fortunate in having women science teachers in school as role models. There was one teacher who made science fun and encouraged the girls even more than the boys as their natural tendencies were to shy away from these subjects.
All these factors served to break down gender barriers I was too young to know existed. I developed the required confidence to pursue my interests in University without really realizing that I was different from my male classmates.
At University, People often assume that I must be exposed to alot of sexism from my classmates and teachers. In fact, I am quite happy to say that I have experienced very little discrimination because of my gender. Of course, there have been the odd incident of an offensive comment here or there, but on the whole I am please to say that I am judged by my work not my gender.
Conclusions:
The conclusions that one could draw from my experience is that the role of environment is vital in choosing a career path. Encouragement from family, friends and teachers seems to have played a big role for women such as myself in choosing a career. On the whole, society still thinks that a science career conflicts with women's traditional roles. In fact, we are all guilty of pre-conceived notions as to what are the "appropriate" roles for men and women. When we think of a nurse, we think of a woman, and when we think of a mechanic, we think of a man. I am sure that many people think that Engineering is too hard or too boring to go into. I hope that I have introduced you to one very exciting area, that is both challenging and permits a great deal of creativity.
titleenglish: Femmes Br@nchées #18 :: A girl's life in Electrical Engineering
titlefrench: Femmes Br@nchées #18 :: A girl's life in Electrical Engineering
bodyfrench:
My name is Tal Arbel. I am a doctoral student in the department of Electrical Engineering at McGill. A question that often comes up is how it is that I - being a woman of many interests - ended up in the sciences and more specifically how I came upon Engineering - a typically male-dominated field. I will tell you a bit about the motivating factors and influences that lead me to a career in science and technology.

First, I will tell you a bit about what I do. I am working in the area of Computer Vision in the Center for Intelligent Machines. The idea behind the center is to build smart machines like robots - capable of changing their behavior by sensing and interpreting their environment, making decisions and plans, and then carrying out those plans by moving around without human intervention. This might include getting a robot to pick up an object, move around an object, inspect it, etc. Computer Vision is a field that focuses on the problem of getting a computer to see and understand what it is seeing. The idea is to acquire visual data using a camera, a laser or others, to extract the interesting features from the image in order to get descriptions of the objects in the scene, to recognize these objects and to interpret the entire scene.

I am working on the problem of getting the robot to recognize objects. This entails placing an object in front of a camera, taking pictures or measuring how far the object is from a laser, and getting the computer to estimate the shape and size of the object. Then, the computer has to figure out which of the objects it has seen already it is looking at.

Personal Motivations:

My personal interest in a field such as computer vision has been primarily linked to the fact that it comprises many different fascinating areas. It involves collaborative efforts by researchers with very different interests, encouraging interdisciplinary activities which transcend the traditional departmental boundaries. These include scientific areas such as neurophysiology, psychology, mathematics, physics.

However, the field is also heavily influenced by other disciplines as well. Vision researchers ask many of the same questions asked by artists over time: How does lighting affect object shape? How does the appearance of objects change when viewed from different angles? An artist must understand these things in order to paint a realistic picture. A vision researcher must take them into account as well because sometimes we can only measure how bright the objects in the scene are and we need to infer shape from that little information. Also we need to get the computer to recognize the object even if it looks very different from different positions and with different lighting.

As well, philosophical questions arise. Vision addresses the issues of: How do we define learning, understanding, cognition, intelligence? It is not a field that simply involves manufacturing widgets, but it involves dreaming up and developing technology that makes you rethink every day processes that we take for granted. For example, when we try to get computers to understand what they are seeing, we must rethink what it means to learn new things. When we recognize objects that we have never seen before, what processes of cognition come into play? What is the difference between knowledge and intelligence? These are issues that we must think about if we wish to get a computer to think on its own.

The field of Artificial Intelligence thought it should be easy to make a computer think on its own. There was much hype when this field was first introduced. They thought it would be simple to show a computer a cup and have it understand what it was. After all, we do these things quite easily as humans. When they began to examine the task more closely, they realized, that mundane, daily acts that we take for granted are not trivial. When we tried to get a robot to pick up a cup off a table, we began to understand that knowing where the cup ends and where the table begins is not easy. How do you get the computer to understand how heavy the cup is by looking at it? How do we get it to estimate how slippery it might be? These things are obvious to us but it is hard to pinpoint what exactly it is that makes us understand these everyday tasks. As a result, there was great dissappointment in the field and people became less interested in the problem of artificial intelligence.

However, other disciplines came to the aid of computer vision. In studying how to get machines to see and perceive, researchers began examining how the most successful working visual system works - namely, the human visual system. Neurologists studying how the brain works were not able to tell us much about how the visual system works, as that part of the brain is relatively not understood. Thus, in order to be able to create an autonomous intelligent machine, computer vision researchers began working in collaboration with neurophysiologists and psychologists in trying to understand how we as humans acquire and process visual information. The goal, of course, was not to mimic human thought, but to understand it sufficiently to be able to borrow ideas for our own thinking machine. It was found that the human visual system is actually very sophisticated and thus building THE artificial vision machine became impossible. The result is that the field is focusing on understanding and solving more specific vision problems in the hopes of putting them together one day.

The fact that these inter-disciplinary connections such as these need to be made is what makes this area interesting.

In addition to the scientific aspect, the benefits of a career in research is that the process is creative. For some people, creativity manifests itself in drawing or painting. For others such as myself, it is through the computer. In either of these cases, one creates connections between ideas where none existed before. In addition, I believe that women in male-dominated areas have an advantage in that their perspective is slightly different than those of the men, providing fresh new insight in their solutions.


Personal Background:

So, having said what I do, how did I end up in this field? Engineering is not a discipline that society encourages women to enter. It is common to think that men are more naturally inclined towards the pure and applied sciences and that women are not only uninterested in such things, but that they are perhaps not naturally talented in math and physics. If such is that case, how is it that women such as myself ended up choosing a career in Engineering research and excelling at it at par with my male colleagues?

In my opinion, the primary influence for women who went on to pursue their interests in science came from the home. As is the case for most of my female colleagues, my father is an Engineer. As such, I was exposed to this career option quite early, learning what it is that he does and deciding if it interested me. I was encouraged to ask questions and my father - excited to have someone to share his interests with - spoke freely of his work and explained alot to me. My parents, taking note of my natural interest and curiosity in how things worked, bought me many books and even a computer and played math games with me at a young age. Although I had a normal childhood and even played with dolls, no one ever told me that these interests were restricted for "boys" and thus were off limits. Only as an adult, did I realize how forward-thinking my parents were.

In addition to my home life, I was fortunate in having women science teachers in school as role models. There was one teacher who made science fun and encouraged the girls even more than the boys as their natural tendencies were to shy away from these subjects.

All these factors served to break down gender barriers I was too young to know existed. I developed the required confidence to pursue my interests in University without really realizing that I was different from my male classmates.

At University, People often assume that I must be exposed to alot of sexism from my classmates and teachers. In fact, I am quite happy to say that I have experienced very little discrimination because of my gender. Of course, there have been the odd incident of an offensive comment here or there, but on the whole I am please to say that I am judged by my work not my gender.


Conclusions:

The conclusions that one could draw from my experience is that the role of environment is vital in choosing a career path. Encouragement from family, friends and teachers seems to have played a big role for women such as myself in choosing a career. On the whole, society still thinks that a science career conflicts with women's traditional roles. In fact, we are all guilty of pre-conceived notions as to what are the "appropriate" roles for men and women. When we think of a nurse, we think of a woman, and when we think of a mechanic, we think of a man. I am sure that many people think that Engineering is too hard or too boring to go into. I hope that I have introduced you to one very exciting area, that is both challenging and permits a great deal of creativity.

bodyenglish:
Secret Radio: Confessions of a Radiophonic Eavesdropper
By Katarina Soukup 

for Les Femmes Branchées, January 31st, 1997

Many people don't notice the secret or hidden radio transmissions that are a part of their everyday lives. There are many things that your run-of-the-mill FM or AM radio cannot detect: transmissions from ambulances, airplanes, armoured cars, trains, taxis, buses, police cars, fire engines, walkie-talkies, and mobile phones.


All of these frequencies are transmitted over public airwaves. And the device you need to tune into these frequencies is.... a radio scanner. Most people know that journalists might use a scanner to monitor police and ambulance radio frequencies to get the scoop on accidents and fires, but what many don't consider is that cell phone conversations can be monitored just like any other two way radio transmission!


New opportunities are opening up for the radiophonic eavesdropper! An utterly irresistable tempatation for some like me... who, I confess! has deligently practiced the art of eavesdropping since childhood. When I was a kid, I was called "Big Ears" not because my lobes were lascivicious, but because I often eschewed the company of other kids to hang out with my mother and her women friends. I loved to sit inconspicuously at the kitchen table and pick up the rich texture of their lives: love affairs, gossip, heartbreaks, and wry commentary on the men they knew. Living in rural Alberta, too, meant using a party line phone Aeno one has a private phone connection and several households share the same line. I spent untold hours trying to control my breathing while listening to the trials and tribulations of my neighbours.


I admit that when my partner showed me the possiblities of listening with a scanner, especially within the cellphone range, I initially feigned shock and disapproval. But as he scanned the frequencies for juicy conversations, my childhood prediliction overcame me. I couldn't help eavesdropping: I was inexplicably drawn to these fragments of intimate confidences exchanged on the public airwaves. Even the manufacturers of radio scanners are caught up in the excitement of eavesdropping: the owner's manual starts off by screaming "Your new portable scanner lets you in on all the action! This scanner gives you direct access to multiple exciting frequencies!"

But is radiophonic eavesdropping ethically or even legally wrong? In Canada at least, there are no legal restrictions on listening in on 2 way radio transmissions. You just can't tape them or broadcast them, or use them against someone. The US has much more stringent legislations: while scanning is technically legal, monitering cell phone ranges isn't! So you have the case, for instance, of the couple who taped the incriminating cell phone conversation that got Newt Gingrich in trouble with a federal ethics committee. They will probably be charged with a crime under the Electronic Communications Privacy act.

Some sound artists are beginning to use the scanner to stir up issues around privacy, ethics, and voyeurism. Robin Rimbaud, a British artist and self-styled "telephone terrorist" who likes to call himself "Scanner" has mounted an experimental sound project. Using a hand held scanner, he incorporates mobile and radio phone conversations in his sound collages. 

About his sound project Scanner, Robin Rimbaud says: "the show forces the listener to confront their own voyeurism as they participate in the collective experience of surveillance. The act of listening to Scanner is an act of mediated voyeurism that implicates the listener in the invasion of others' privacy".
"The scans are both alien and scary," he says, "in what they reveal about those around you and at the same time are chilling in their familiarity".
He claims that he wants the work to illustrate what he calls the "illusion of privacy". "I would question that such a thing as privacy still exists, when your email is electronically prone to being read, where closed circuit t.v. follows your every movement".
Is Mister Scanner merely paranoid about how completely we are being surveilled? a creepy immoral voyeur (a category in which I must include myself)? are radio scanners ethical? I leave that for you to answer for yourself.

If you want more info on scanners and how to buy one and what to do with it once you've got in your hot little hands, there is a pretty thorough Introduction to Scanning on the web: ftp://rtfm.mit.edu/pub/usenet-by-group/rec.radio.scanner/Introduction_to_Scanning
alt.radio.scanner (newsgroup) 
In Montreal: www.wildstar.net/~plaws/scan/Montreal/ (broken link)
(Canadian scanner page)
www.snm.com/~wlhadley/Monitor/Lists/CA/ (broken link)
Also for those interested in checking out the Scanner sound project, you can do so via the web:
http://www.obsolete.com/scanner/

bodyenglish:
Wired Women - The Film: A xx 2 minute review 


Kim Sawchuk

 February 2, 1996
Screening January 15, 1996 

	
		
			 
			
			 
			
			 I don't know if Morgan Eliot who made 
			Wired Women intended to wire me up, but that was the effect this film 
			had on me. It put me in a tizzy. Trying to emulate MTV's style of quick 
			pace editing and jittery hand held camera movements, the film induced 
			nausea in more than one spectator at the studio xx screening a few weeks 
			ago. Perhaps it wasn't meant to be shown on the big screen, which made 
			me feel like I was on an airplane encountering turbulence. Perhaps the 
			value of the screening was precisely to remind me that the medium still 
			matters. 
			
			I found the content equally tough to take. What promises to be a survey 
			of women's use of the net is less a documentary in my opinion, and more 
			a promo for compuserve. The moral tale of the film is embodied in the 
			story of the narrator Elvira Kurtz, who magically transforms from technophobe 
			to technofile after seeing all these women doing it. Anything announcing 
			itself as a documentary should take into account divergent practices, 
			ask some questions, show a litttle scepticism. 
			
			The filmamaker depicts the potential of the net as a marketing tool for 
			female entrepeneurs who run cofee shops or sell jewellery for piercings. 
			When the crew visits the Banff Centre, curator Catherine Crowston and 
			media arts director Sara Diamond are overshadowed by head of publicity 
			who is wowed by the speed at which she can make contacts. Okay, I have 
			no problem with people who show a little initiative, financial or otherwise, 
			and I also know that we all need money, women in particular. But as a 
			survey, the practices represented lean heavily towards two poles: Business 
			and Relationships. 
			
			The film spends far too long lovingly gazing on a mother-daughter relationship 
			sustained while daughter is away at college in Isreal. The internet was 
			able to help mom know her daughter was all right during the Gulf War: 
			no mention of the context or the politics of the people involved. To be 
			frank, after too many minutes getting to know the details of their personal 
			lives, I just didn't care. Relationship number two is introduced under 
			the rubric cybersex: a guy and the girl meet on-line (OL) via a news group 
			on the Monkees and decide to meet each other off line or in (RL) for the 
			benefit of the camera. This section wasn't so annoying to me for it allowed 
			itself to display a bit of humour, and not at their expense. 
			
			But these were very conventional people, and the made for t.v. film steered 
			away from any hint of anything naughty that's out there for women, save 
			the possibility of a bit of silver for your navel. Dykes, gays, lesbians 
			weren't very evident in the film's pandering to the safety of heterosexuality. 
			The film touches on porn and sex, which Sara Diamond points out isn't 
			much of an issue and avoids any discussion of feminist organizations, 
			politics, artists collectives, or some of the funky cyber chick stuff. 
			It's tame but rugged individualism of a sort for girls. Turn on your modems 
			and ride into the new frontier. 
			
			I've been very harsh. The film does have its moments. I think that the 
			best lines in the film are uttered by Diana in Montreal, who thinks of 
			her computer as just another appliance and leaves it in the kitchen. Diana, 
			who is amazed she can order meat on the net, and tells the hilarious story 
			of how miscommuncations can happen. When they talked about SNOW, she thought 
			he was talking about the weather, he thought she wanted to score some 
			dope. 
			
			Maybe I'm old, bitchy, tired; but I wanted more. 
			
			My minutes are up. I hope that at the next femmes branchées one 
			of you takes up the challenge of reviewing some aspect of tech-life, be 
			it movie, book, or CD-ROM.

bodyenglish:
wired_women: The Book: An xx 5 minute review -
Katarina Soukup

wired_women: The Book: An xx 5 minute review
Katarina Soukup



Wired_Women: Gender and 
the New Realities in Cyberspace
Lynn Cherny
Elizabeth Reba Weise
Seal Books
$22.75 CDN

June 21, 1996


	
		
			
			 
			
			 
			
			 
			
			
			Who says women use the internet just to 
			send email to their pals?
			
			Not the "Wired Women" featured in a new anthology edited by Lynn Cherny 
			and Elizabeth Reba Weise. This book puts the spotlight on those who 
			ventured into the wild wild west of cyberspace and lived to tell the 
			tale! Sometimes exhilerating, sometimes frightening, these cyber adventures 
			explore the numerous possibilities, pleasures, and ,yep, even dangers 
			the Internet and all of its virtual spaces can offer women.
			
			Susan Clerc takes a look at how pre-Internet female-dominated fan culture 
			has been transposed into newsnet and on-line mailing lists. Meet the 
			X Philes (that's P-H-I-L-E-S) who have attracted the attention of scriptwriters 
			for the cult show! Sign up for the David Duchovny Estrogen Brigade!
			
			Ex-patriot staff-writer at Wired magazine, Paulina Bersook, gives us 
			the lowdown on a magazine I've always felt was Cosmo for gear geeks. 
			Ms P. astutely reveals the publication's gender blindness and gender 
			blunders.
			
			Another story details the attempts of Carnegie Mellon University (CMU 
			--also known as "Censor Me University") to delete any and all newsgroups 
			on netnews that contained the word "sex" (including discussions like 
			alt.safe.sex) in the name of protecting "women, children, animals, and 
			the like [!]".
			
			Drastic measures require drastic action and hence the "Clitoral Hoods", 
			a women's sex positive direct action group, was born. Their mission: 
			to fight the university's patronizing, hypocritical attitude towards 
			women Internet users by "empowering women to protect ourselves with 
			the tools of the Internet: our wits, our keyboards, and our fuscia flame-throwers".
			
			Other instances of female solidarity in cyberspace abound. For instance, 
			Wired_Women chronicles the importance of "Systers", an on-line mailing 
			list that serves over 1500 women interested in science. Before other 
			women's groups or the media, this mailing list was the first to sound 
			the call to arms over one of the biggest toy scandals ever to hit Mattel 
			Inc.--I refer, of course, to the Talking Barbie "math-is-tough" fiasco 
			of 1993.
			
			But as much as we want it to be, the internet is not always the happy 
			Hyper Nation overflowing with the milk of human kindness. Several stories 
			in this book explore the big, baaaaaaahhhhd neighbourhoods of cyberspace. 
			In trying to research an article on hacker culture, for instance, Netta 
			Gilboa went "to hell and back" during her forays into the Hacker Underworld 
			which lurks within various channels of the IRC (inter-relay chat) network.
			
			Hackers can be the meanest people on the Net, and the ones Gilboa encountered 
			were probably some of the nastiest. Suspecting a Net Narc --or even 
			worse, a newbie!-- hackers gained access to her account, deleted important 
			email, hacked her phone line, and conference-called her answering machine 
			just to leave a slew of insults and threats.
			
			Yet Gilboa is entangled in a classic love-hate relationship: despite 
			some heavy-duty hacker harassment, she remains utterly fascinated by 
			the motivations, personalities, and strategies of this ruthlessly secretive 
			cyberculture.
			
			Another case of women finding cyberspace to be a hostile place is recounted 
			by Stephanie Brail, the object of an Internet harrassment saga which 
			caught the eye of the American media. Brail merely defended a woman 
			writing to the newsgroup 'alt.fanzines' who wanted to to discuss Riot 
			Grrl zines.
			
			This detonated a flame war with a male whose tactics went frighteningly 
			beyond the parametres of the usual "shut-up bitch" and "wanna fuck" 
			harrassment women encounter everyday on the Net --and which Brail says 
			she could have easily dealt with. Wired_Women offers some advice on 
			how to avoid on-line harrassment, and what you can do (not much!) in 
			the event it ever does come your way.
			
			For those who've been to these parts of the HyperNation, the CyberNeighbourhood, 
			or whatever you choose to call the ethereal space mapped by electronic 
			networks, the anecdotes contained in Wired_Women provide acurate, amusing 
			analysis which will have you nodding your head in recognition.
			
			For those who've never visited a MUD, plumbed the depths of the hacker 
			Underworld, or delved into the on-line fan scene, these stories will 
			make you wanna seek out these places and experience both their thrills 
			and their spills.
			
			Unfortunately, the book lacks the voices and experiences of women of 
			colour out there in cyberspace --which the editors admit and attribute 
			to a dearth of wired women of colour available to write a piece for 
			the anthology. Telling evidence that the promised Internet democracy, 
			where relations are untarnished by race or gender, is still --and probably 
			always will be-- mere utopian rhetoric
			
			The articles in this book are snappy, sometimes snarky, but they come 
			from true internet afficiandos who are interested in clearing wide spaces 
			for women on the electronic frontier. Ultimately, Wired_Women is about 
			encouraging woman to go on-line, to explore both the delights and the 
			dangers of what is out there.
			
			A woman's travelogue for a whole new world --definitely not for the 
			armchair tourist.
			
			
			To listen to a RealAudio 
			interview with Elizabeth Weise, one of the editors of wired_women, 
			click here!
titleenglish: Femmes Br@nchées #_ :: Wired Women: The Book: An xx 5 minute review
titlefrench: Femmes Br@nchées #_ :: Wired Women: The Book: An xx 5 minute review

			and Elizabeth Reba Weise. This book puts the spotlight on those who 
			ventured into the wild wild west of cyberspace and lived to tell the 
			tale! Sometimes exhilerating, sometimes frightening, these cyber adventures 
			explore the numerous possibilities, pleasures, and ,yep, even dangers 
			the Internet and all of its virtual spaces can offer women.
			
			Susan Clerc takes a look at how pre-Internet female-dominated fan culture 
			has been transposed into newsnet and on-line mailing lists. Meet the 
			X Philes (that's P-H-I-L-E-S) who have attracted the attention of scriptwriters 
			for the cult show! Sign up for the David Duchovny Estrogen Brigade!
			
			Ex-patriot staff-writer at Wired magazine, Paulina Bersook, gives us 
			the lowdown on a magazine I've always felt was Cosmo for gear geeks. 
			Ms P. astutely reveals the publication's gender blindness and gender 
			blunders.
			
			Another story details the attempts of Carnegie Mellon University (CMU 
			--also known as "Censor Me University") to delete any and all newsgroups 
			on netnews that contained the word "sex" (including discussions like 
			alt.safe.sex) in the name of protecting "women, children, animals, and 
			the like [!]".
			
			Drastic measures require drastic action and hence the "Clitoral Hoods", 
			a women's sex positive direct action group, was born. Their mission: 
			to fight the university's patronizing, hypocritical attitude towards 
			women Internet users by "empowering women to protect ourselves with 
			the tools of the Internet: our wits, our keyboards, and our fuscia flame-throwers".
			
			Other instances of female solidarity in cyberspace abound. For instance, 
			Wired_Women chronicles the importance of "Systers", an on-line mailing 
			list that serves over 1500 women interested in science. Before other 
			women's groups or the media, this mailing list was the first to sound 
			the call to arms over one of the biggest toy scandals ever to hit Mattel 
			Inc.--I refer, of course, to the Talking Barbie "math-is-tough" fiasco 
			of 1993.
			
			But as much as we want it to be, the internet is not always the happy 
			Hyper Nation overflowing with the milk of human kindness. Several stories 
			in this book explore the big, baaaaaaahhhhd neighbourhoods of cyberspace. 
			In trying to research an article on hacker culture, for instance, Netta 
			Gilboa went "to hell and back" during her forays into the Hacker Underworld 
			which lurks within various channels of the IRC (inter-relay chat) network.
			
			Hackers can be the meanest people on the Net, and the ones Gilboa encountered 
			were probably some of the nastiest. Suspecting a Net Narc --or even 
			worse, a newbie!-- hackers gained access to her account, deleted important 
			email, hacked her phone line, and conference-called her answering machine 
			just to leave a slew of insults and threats.
			
			Yet Gilboa is entangled in a classic love-hate relationship: despite 
			some heavy-duty hacker harassment, she remains utterly fascinated by 
			the motivations, personalities, and strategies of this ruthlessly secretive 
			cyberculture.
			
			Another case of women finding cyberspace to be a hostile place is recounted 
			by Stephanie Brail, the object of an Internet harrassment saga which 
			caught the eye of the American media. Brail merely defended a woman 
			writing to the newsgroup 'alt.fanzines' who wanted to to discuss Riot 
			Grrl zines.
			
			This detonated a flame war with a male whose tactics went frighteningly 
			beyond the parametres of the usual "shut-up bitch" and "wanna fuck" 
			harrassment women encounter everyday on the Net --and which Brail says 
			she could have easily dealt with. Wired_Women offers some advice on 
			how to avoid on-line harrassment, and what you can do (not much!) in 
			the event it ever does come your way.
			
			For those who've been to these parts of the HyperNation, the CyberNeighbourhood, 
			or whatever you choose to call the ethereal space mapped by electronic 
			networks, the anecdotes contained in Wired_Women provide acurate, amusing 
			analysis which will have you nodding your head in recognition.
			
			For those who've never visited a MUD, plumbed the depths of the hacker 
			Underworld, or delved into the on-line fan scene, these stories will 
			make you wanna seek out these places and experience both their thrills 
			and their spills.
			
			Unfortunately, the book lacks the voices and experiences of women of 
			colour out there in cyberspace --which the editors admit and attribute 
			to a dearth of wired women of colour available to write a piece for 
			the anthology. Telling evidence that the promised Internet democracy, 
			where relations are untarnished by race or gender, is still --and probably 
			always will be-- mere utopian rhetoric
			
			The articles in this book are snappy, sometimes snarky, but they come 
			from true internet afficiandos who are interested in clearing wide spaces 
			for women on the electronic frontier. Ultimately, Wired_Women is about 
			encouraging woman to go on-line, to explore both the delights and the 
			dangers of what is out there.
			
			A woman's travelogue for a whole new world --definitely not for the 
			armchair tourist.
			
			
			To listen to a RealAudio 
			interview with Elizabeth Weise, one of the editors of wired_women, 
			click here!

bodyenglish:
Performance by Kim Sawchuck.
This is the script of a short performance piece, with musical accompaniment on the kazoo.


 


Bye Bye Barbara 


	
		
			
			 
			
			
			 
			
			
			 presented Dec. 14, 1996 at studio XX 
			
			by Kim Sawchuk
			
			
			 This is the script of 
			a short performance piece, with musical accompaniment on the kazoo.
			
			
			 
			
			
			
			 This is a Political Service Anouncement 
			brought to you by Studio XX.
			
			
			 
			
			
			I'm Kim Sawchuk. 
			
			
			sing: 
			 
			
			
			 We love you Conrad 
			Oh yes we do
			We love you Conrad
			And we'll be true
			Because you're with us
			We're blue
			Oh Conrad we love you! 
			
			
			 
			
			
			
			 That's blue as in neo-conservative Tory 
			blue.This isn't Baywatch. It's Barb watch. More specifically Barbara 
			Amiel-Black watch.
			
			
			 Former editor of the Toronto Sun, columnist 
			for McLeans magazine and the London Telegraph, as well as an author 
			of several books of non-fiction, Ms. Amiel Black's malignant presence 
			seems to be growing. She is now International Affairs Correspondent 
			for the Southam Presses, as well as vice president of Hollinger Inc. 
			a world wide media conglomerate owned by her husband, Mr. C. 
			
			
			 That's Conrad, Conrad Black who controls 
			the shares of over 60 percent of the newspapers in English Canada. Conrad 
			maintains that we shouldn't be concerned about this monopoly. He can 
			separate ideology from ownership. He has brought Canadians nothing but 
			quality reporting- like the writings of Barbara Amiel Black.
			
			
			 wedding march on 
			kazoo...
			
			
			 
			
			
			This dynamic neo-Con duo, Barbara and Conrad, were married 
			in a civil cermony in London, England on July 21, 1992. 
			
			
			 Now, don't confuse this Barbara with 
			those other benign Barbara's: Barbara Streisand, Barbara Walters, Barbara 
			Frum or even Barbara Bush, add a Barbara of your own. This Barbie is 
			no doll.
			
			
			 Although she now resides in England, 
			Barbara Amiel Black is our own home grown "lady against women." And 
			if any of you caught her on this Hour Has Twenty Two Minutes she seems 
			to be acquiring an accent. A British accent. A British upper class accent. 
			It must be from rubbing shoulders with the rich and famous like Lady 
			Di, Lord King, and Henry Kissinger who have all been spotted at recent 
			dinner parties. Oh yes, it's Dynasty Canajun style.
			
			
			 Barbara and Conrad; Conrad and Barbara. 
			She supplies the glitz, the taste they say, he the bucks. 
			
			
			 But why, oh why, am I wasting my breathe 
			and your time providing a Political Service Announcement on a woman 
			who I so gleefully love to despise?
			
			
			 Quality reporting.
			
			
			 Maybe you've read one of her McLean's 
			articles, such as:
			
			
			 "Firing a 'hooker' is an 
			employers right" (Dec. 18, 1995)
			
			
			 "The madness of the unisex 
			experiment"  (Aug. 28, 1995) 
			
			
			 "Baleful feminism and O.J. 
			Simpson" (Feb. 6, 1995)
			
			
			 or my personal favorite, 
			 "In defense of elitism: benefits for everyone" (July 
			31, 1995) 
			
			
			 I'm confused and a little concerned as 
			a writer and a member of Studio XX. 
			
			
			 After all Ms. Barbara Amiel Black has 
			suggested that if you want to promote Canadian literature, "you can 
			do more by giving to the defense budget than to agencies like the Canada 
			Council. " (May 1, 1995) But 's not only the headlines. This is a woman 
			connected to powerful interests like the National Business Council a 
			right wing lobby group in Ottawa who awarded Ms. Amiel Black their highest 
			accolade for defending her brand of individualism and the rights of 
			the free market against creeping statism. 
			
			
			sing: 
			 
			
			
			 Me and me against the world, 
			Sometimes it feels like me and me against the world... 
			
			
			 Perhaps you have noticed her syndicated 
			International Affairs Column on page B6 of Saturday's Gazette, a paper 
			now owned by Conrad. This intrepid International Affairs Columnist reports 
			from abroad, warning of the dangers of excessive liberalism at fault 
			for "poor education; rising health care; young criminals; and welfare 
			dependency." (Aug. 31, 96) 
			
			
			 More than once she has made me steamed. 
			International Affairs columnist. Now normally, this is the type of editorial 
			position that you would expect to be about worldly political issues. 
			And sometimes it is. But sometimes it is political in ways unexpected. 
			
			
			
			 To give credit where credit is due our 
			Ms. Amiel Black dains to discuss issues domestic in her International 
			Affairs column, giving a whole new meaing to that phrase the "personal 
			is political". Issues like "Violence: a private affair: British soccer 
			player shouldn't be vilified because his wife has a black eye and bruises." 
			(Nov. 9, 1996) After all, a little aggressive behaviour by men is natural, 
			unlike the horrid unnaturalness of same sex couples and gay parents 
			.
			
			
			 Natural and unnatural are favorite terms 
			in her vocabularly and she seems able to divine who is on what side 
			of this border. It must be divination since most of her writing is low 
			on research and high on bombastic rhetoric. 
			
			
			 Well fight fire with fire I say. And 
			that's why I'm here today. 
			
			
			 Our Barbara seems particularly vexed 
			feminism, insipid daughter of liberalism, specifically blamed for mixed 
			sex hospital wards, the demise of the modern family, and of course the 
			sorry condition of "Henpecked men who carry feminist torch" Yes, a "feminised 
			society" deprives we women of these take-charge men. " (Nov. 23, 1996) 
			
			
			
			 Men like Conrad Black?
			
			
			 Perhaps she should be concerned about 
			such issues. After all, this is her third marriage. (meow)
			
			
			 But I guess that this time she found 
			Mr. Right!
			
			
			 Barbara Amiel is a woman of power, no 
			let me rephrase that an anti-feminist, homophobe occupying her own version 
			of the moral high ground. A murky stew of libertarianism spiced by financial 
			comfort- a dream world located on the other side of the pond where she 
			can pontificate about the insipid character of all of us, francophones 
			and anglophones, back here in the colonies. 
			
			
			 Bye Bye blackbird 
			on Kazoo...
			(get audience to snap fingers and join in) 
			
			
			  
			
			
			The world's a mess and life's the pits Don't blame the 
			rich, blame feminists! Bye bye Barbara 
			
			
			 The homeless or the single 
			moms Forget them all, they're welfare scum Bye Bye Barbara 
			
			
			 Life's too short to show 
			any compassion By our papers, find out what's RIGHT in fashion 
			
			
			 So if your bank account is 
			low. That's too bad, we've got dough!! 
			
			
			  
			
			
			Barbara BYE BYE!!!

bodyenglish:
Continuing the 25th anniversary celebration of La Centrale was a web art show curated by Gail Bourgeois in collaboration with Studio XX. The theme of the show explores notions of horror, abjection, love and a preoccupation with liminal states and transformation.

The Artists:

Annie Abrahams (France) - Beinghuman
Natalie Bookchin (Los Angeles) - Intruder
Susan Harman (Vancouver) - Navigating the Body
Julie Lapalme (Halifax) - Orphan Train - Trained Tales
Christy Sheffield Sanford (Florida) - Rockgarden of Love

The show ran from April 17th to May 30th, 1999 at La Centrale - Galerie Powerhouse 460, rue Ste-Catherine Ouest/West, #506 and on-line.
bodyfrench:
À l'occasion du 25e anniversaire de La Centrale, Gail Bourgeois a organisé une exposition thématique d'art web, en collaboration avec le Studio XX. Les oeuvres traitent d'horreur, d'abjection et d'amour, et elles abordent les questions de transformation et d'états liminaux. 

Les artistes:
Annie Abrahams (France) - Beinghuman
Natalie Bookchin (Los Angeles) - Intruder
Susan Harman (Vancouver) - Navigating the Body
Julie Lapalme (Halifax) - Orphan Train - Trained Tales
Christy Sheffield Sanford (Florida) - Rockgarden of Love
L'exposition a eu lieu du 17 avril au 30 mai 1999 à La Centrale-Galerie Powerhouse 460, rue Ste-Catherine Ouest/West, #506 et a été diffusée sur la site de La Centrale.

bodyenglish: tara rodgers:: butterfly effects, multichannel sound performance  magali babin :: onion router, audio interactive performance with projection (resident artist at Studio XX)  beginning with a conversation with the artists  Thursday March 20th 2008, 8:00 PM Entrance Fee: 5$ Galerie B-312, 372 Ste-Catherine Ouest, espace 403  A Studio XX and Galerie B-312 Co-production    Biographies ::  Tara Rodgers is a composer and writer from upstate New York and now based in Montreal. As Analog Tara, she has performed electronic music and led recording workshops over the last 10 years. She has exhibited sound and video art across the U.S. and Canada. Her recent work uses the programming language SuperCollider to sonify large-scale patterns of living. "Butterfly Effects," her computer music composition based on butterfly migrations, was awarded a 2006 Frog Peak Experimental Music Prize, and the 2007 New Genre Composition Prize from the International Alliance for Women in Music. Tara was a visiting professor at the Museum School in Boston in 2004-05, and a Canada-U.S. Fulbright scholar in 2006-07. She earned an MFA in Electronic Music at Mills College in 2006, and is now a PhD student at McGill. She is editing Pink Noises, an anthology of interviews with women who are electronic musicians and sound artists. http://www.safety-valve.org/  Magali Babin art audio [abat-jour, braise, cadeau, dents, eau, filles, grenouilles, housse, ipéca, jambes, k7, lave-glace, marche, neige, os, peau, quincaillerie, radio, salive, tissus, utérus, viande, watts, xylophone, yeuse, zinc.] also... [apple, bee, caviar, disk, echo, friends, gum, hockey, icicle, jeans, kleenex, light, money, nature, orange, plates, quire, rice, slat, television, umbrella, vomit, walkie-talkie, xerox, young men, zoom distortion] « Between my hands a banal object, usual, a road to scan with the ear. Tourist of my day-to-day life, little movements make me hear the places of a new sonic geography » — Magali Babin «… Exploring the microcosm of metallic objects that she makes vibrating, Magali creates in a same gesture a music as much minimalist as geant. » Productions SuperMusique
bodyfrench: tara rodgers  :: butterfly effects, musique générativemagali babin :: onion router, action audio interactive avec vidéo (artiste en résidence au Studio XX)précédé d’une discussion avec les artistesJeudi 20 mars 2008, 20hentrée : 5$ Galerie B-312, 372 Ste-Catherine Ouest, espace 403Une coproduction du Studio XX et de la Galerie B-312Biographies ::Tara Rodgers Originaire de l'état de New York, la compositrice et une auteure Tara Rodgers vit actuellement à Montréal. Sous le pseudonyme de Analog Tara, elle se produit sur les scènes de musique électronique et dirige des ateliers d'enregistrement depuis plus de 10 ans. Son travail d'art vidéo et sonore a été présenté à travers les États-Unis et le Canada. Ses travaux récents utilisent le langage de programmation SuperCollider pour sonoriser des patterns (motifs) de vie, grand-format. "Butterfly Effects", une composition de musique par ordinateur basée sur la migration des papillons, a été récompensée au Frog Peak Experimental Music Prize (06) et a reçu le New Genre Composition Prize du International Alliance for Women in Music (07). Tara a été professeur invitée au Museum School de Boston en 04-05. Elle a reçu la bourse Canada-U.S. Fulbright (06-07). Détentrice d'une maîtrise en musique électronique du Mills College (06), elle poursuit actuellement un doctorat à l'université McGill. Elle prépare la publication de Pink Noises, une anthologie d'entrevues réalisées avec des femmes en musique électronique et artistes sonores. http://www.safety-valve.org/Magali Babinart audio [abat-jour, braise, cadeau, dents, eau, filles, grenouilles, housse, ipéca, jambes, k7, lave-glace, marche, neige, os, peau, quincaillerie, radio, salive, tissus, utérus, viande, watts, xylophone, yeuse, zinc.]also... [apple, bee, caviar, disk, echo, friends, gum, hockey, icicle, jeans, kleenex, light, money, nature, orange, plates, quire, rice, slat, television, umbrella, vomit, walkie-talkie, xerox, young men, zoom distortion]« Entre mes mains un objet banal, usuel, un chemin à scruter par l’oreille. Touriste de mon quotidien, de petits gestes me font entendre les lieux d’une nouvelle géographie sonore. » Magali BabinLa musicalité de Magali se démarque par l’expression des extrêmes sonores; du minimal strident au noïse planant. « …Explorant le microcosme des objets métalliques qu’elle fait vibrer, Magali crée par un même geste une musique aussi minimaliste que géante. » Productions SuperMusique

bodyenglish: On Thursday, February 7th, Studio XX Board Vice-President Hélène Prévost was honored with a Lifetime Tribute. Montreal’s musical and radio phonic community gathered at the Society for Art and Technology (SAT) to pay homage and celebrate.  The event underscored the exceptional lifelong contribution of this Radio-Canada radio director and her inexhaustible passion and curiosity for new music in all its forms.  You will find an excerpt of Navire Night at this address : http://www.radio-canada.ca/radio/navire/ and more information about the event follows shortly.  The event's artistic team and organizers: Monique Savoie, Chantal Dumas, Marie Marais and Micheline Richard.
bodyfrench: Hélène Prévost, vice-présidente de notre conseil d’administration, fut célébrée le jeudi 7 février dernier. Tout le milieu musical et radiophonique s’était réuni à La SAT (Montréal) pour lui rendre hommage. Cet événement est venu souligner le travail exceptionnel de cette femme réalisatrice à la radio de Radio-Canada qui au cours de 30 ans d’activités a manifesté passion et curiosité pour les musiques nouvelles de tout azimut.Vous trouverez quelques traces du Navire Night à cette adresse : http://www.radio-canada.ca/radio/navire/ et plus d’infos sur l’événement très bientôt sur le site du Studio XX.  Les conceptrices et organisatrices de la soirée: Monique Savoie, Chantal Dumas, Marie Marais et Micheline Richard.

bodyenglish: Femmes br@nchées 66 Salon [Dec. 13] :: Top Chrono Thursday December 13th 2007, 5h30 to 7h30 PM @ Studio XX :: 4001 Berri St., Suite 201 Entrance fee : 5$, free for XX members. The only limitation will be their imagination. However, the length of their session will be determined by the cast of a dice! bodyfrench: Salon Femmes br@nchées 66 [13 déc] :: Top Chrono Jeudi 13 décembre 2007, 17h30 à 19h30 au Studio XX, 4001, rue Berri espace 201 Prix d'entrée : 5$, entrée libre pour les membres.  Top chrono.  10 femmes artistes ont été invitées à participer à ce Top Chrono 2007.  Les règles du jeu sont simples : les artistes présentent un travail en cours ou encore réalisent une performance. La seule limite est leur imagination. Par contre, la durée de la performance sera déterminée par le lancer du dé. bodyenglish: Dates: mid-november 2007 to end of January 2008  Length : 8 weeks Format: thematic residencyMagali Babin is a well-known Montreal sound artist, admired for her delicate and minimalistic style. During her residency, Magali will set-up her technical playstation for a future audio and visual interactive performance, inspired by TOR. TOR (The Onion Router) is a decentralized network enabling the user to render internet connections anonymous through an onion router technique (via superimposition). Conceptually, Magali questions the relationship to intimacy, both within a technological context or a public environment. Her residency will allow her to become familiar with Pure Data software which will be used to create an interactive environment. This research project will result in a working set-up for further experimentation regarding surveillance techniques, simulation concepts and technological hoaxes. Magali will present the results of her research as a live performance in the near future. Stay tuned...! Touriste de mon quotidien, de petits gestes me font entendre les lieux d’une nouvelle géographie sonore. » Magali Babin « Between my hands a banal object, usual, a road to scan with the ear. Tourist of my day-to-day life, little movements make me hear the places of a new sonic geography » — Magali Babin La musicalité de Magali se démarque par l’expression des extrêmes sonores; du minimal strident au noïse planant. « …Explorant le microcosme des objets métalliques qu’elle fait vibrer, Magali crée par un même geste une musique aussi minimaliste que géante. » Productions SuperMusique «… Exploring the microcosm of metallic objects that she makes vibrating, Magali creates in a same gesture a music as much minimalist as geant. » Productions SuperMusique
bodyfrench: Magali Babin   Date: mi-novembre 2007 à la fin janvier 2008  Durée: 8 semaines Format de l'œuvre : résidence thématique Magali Babin, artiste de la performance sonore aux couleurs minimalistes bien connue de la scène montréalaise, est en résidence au Studio XX. Durant cette résidence, Magali Babin va préparer une interface de jeu en vue d’une performance interactive audio et visuelle, inspirée par TOR. TOR (The Onion Router) est un réseau décentralisé qui permet, grâce à une technique de routage en oignon (par superposition) de rendre anonyme les connexions sur Internet. Conceptuellement, Magali questionne le rapport à l’intimité dans un contexte de technologie en réseau ou d’un environnement public. Cette résidence lui permettra de se familiariser avec le logiciel Puredata qui sera utilisé pour créer un environnement interactif. Ce projet de recherche est la mise en place d’un terrain d’expérimentation à propos des techniques de surveillance, des concepts de simulation et des canulars technologiques. Magali présentera ultérieurement en performance le résultat de ses recherches. Date à surveiller ... Biographie ::  art audio abat-jour, braise, cadeau, dents, eau, filles, grenouilles, housse, ipéca, jambes, k7, lave-glace, marche,neige, os, peau, quincaillerie, radio, salive, tissus, utérus, viande, watts, xylophone, yeuse, zinc. also... apple, bee, caviar, disk, echo, friends, gum, hockey, icicle, jeans, kleenex, light, money, nature, orange, plates, quire, rice, slat, television, umbrella, vomit, walkie-talkie, xerox, young men, zoom distortion « Entre mes mains un objet banal, usuel, un chemin à scruter par l’oreille. Touriste de mon quotidien, de petits gestes me font entendre les lieux d’une nouvelle géographie sonore. » Magali Babin La musicalité de Magali se démarque par l’expression des extrêmes sonores; du minimal strident au noïse planant. « …Explorant le microcosme des objets métalliques qu’elle fait vibrer, Magali crée par un même geste une musique aussi minimaliste que géante. » Productions SuperMusique

bodyenglish:
Come and meet performance artist Constanza Camelo as she presents her project: Dilater ou contracter l'univers
(Expanding or Contracting the Universe) 
+ 
Launch of the web magazine .dpi 12 
Wednesday, June 25th 5:30 - 7:30 PM
Entrance Fee : Free
at the Studio XX : 4001 rue Berri, suite 201
Sherbrooke metro
info : 514-845-7934 
On May 7, Constanza Camelo performed the project Dilater ou contracter l'univers, une performance (Expanding or Contracting the Universe, a performance). A group of 13 immigrants were blindfolded with a passport and escorted by MIRA dogs, they walked through the hallways of the Berri-UQAM metro station to the sound of national anthems playing back on portable speakers. The group then moved to another section of the station for a staged live portrait. The artist will discuss the project in the presence of the immigrants who participated in the event.
In 2005, Constanza Camelo took the standard training course for the visually handicapped offered by the MIRA Foundation. This instruction enabled her to discover the primary reflex mechanisms for getting around with a guide dog. She conceived the project "Expand or Contract the Universe" as a result of this experience.
The aim of this project is to explore how the process of perception as well as visual and motor representation, express the various levels of adaptation to the new host area. This approach will show the territorial occupations communicated by the symbolically “handicapped” migrant.
This interactive sound project was produced during a residency held at Studio XX.
Biography :: 
Constanza Camelo's work is essentially based on territorial occupations through the body in performance art, video performance and installAction. The body — object and subject — explores interactions between different transdiciplinary postures during different ephemeral cohabitations of public and private spaces.
In addition, C. Camelo is a cofounder of the artist collective We are not Speedy Gonzales, collective who creates situations around the dynamics of the transcultural identity. She is also a board member of the artist's run center DARE DARE. She lectures at the Université du Québec à Montréal. 
----------

.dpi 12, the season’s last issue 
.dpi closes its series on the theme of mobility with a sixth issue exploring works and actions that use and misuse technologies, at times with activist intentions.
In this issue: An article on the West Coast activist collective from the Calit2 Lab at the University of California, San Diego, who created the Transborder Immigrant Tool, a device that helps immigrants finding their way in the desert; An interview with Constanza Camelo about her performance Dilater ou contracter l'univers (Expanding and Contracting the Universe), produced during a residency at Studio XX, where she questions the notion of territory and immigrants; And a piece about Mobile Digital Commons Networks’ The Haunting, a ghost-chasing game that invests the Mont-Royal and rethinks the production of locative media.
And to take along those evening summer strolls, .dpi offers two Ipod-downloadable flipbooks by artist Natacha Clitandre.
bodyfrench:
Rencontre avec l'artiste de performance Constanza Camelo
autour de son projet : Dilater ou contracter l'univers
+ 
lancement .dpi no 12
25 juin 2008, 17h30
entrée libre
Au Studio XX : 4001 rue Berri, local 201
métro Sherbrooke
info : 514-845-7934 
Le 7 mai dernier, Constanza Camelo présentait Dilater ou contracter l'univers, une performance où un groupe de 13 immigrants rendus aveugles par un passeport qui leur cachait les yeux traversait les couloirs du métro Berri-UQAM accompagnés de chiens-guides de la Fondation Mira au son d'hymnes nationaux diffusés sur des haut-parleurs portatifs. Puis ils allaient former un tableau vivant dans un autre corridor du métro. C'est de ce projet dont elle va nous entretenir en compagnie des immigrants ayant participé au projet. 
Constanza Camelo a suivi auprès de la Fondation MIRA (2005) un cours type offert aux personnes dotées d’handicaps visuels. Ceci lui a permis de découvrir les mécanismes primaires de déplacement avec le chien guide. C'est à partir de cette expérience qu’elle a imaginé le projet Dilater ou contracter l’univers.
Ce projet a pour but d’expérimenter la manière dont les processus de perception et de représentation visuelles et moteurs expriment les divers niveaux d'adaptation au nouveau territoire d’accueil. Ce serait une façon de matérialiser des occupations territoriales véhiculées par le corps symboliquement «handicapé» du migrant.
Ce projet comprenant un aspect interactif et sonore a été réalisé dans le cadre d'une résidence au Studio XX.

Biographie ::
La pratique de Constanza Camelo matérialise des occupations territoriales véhiculées par le corps en art action, performance-vidéo et installAction. Le corps — objet et sujet —explore des interactions entre divers dispositifs transdisciplinaires opérés lors de cohabitations éphémères d'espaces publics et privés.
Par ailleurs, C. Camelo est cofondatrice du collectif We are not Speedy Gonzales, collectif qui met en scène une dynamique de l'identité transculturelle. Elle s'implique également dans la diffusion de l'art en tant que membre du Conseil d’administration de DARE DARE, centre de diffusion d’art multidisciplinaire de Montréal. Elle travaille comme chargée de cours à l’Université du Québec à Montréal.
---------- 

.dpi 12, dernier numéro de la saison. 
Après avoir consacré 5 numéros au thème de la mobilité, .dpi clôt sa série avec une dernière parution qui aborde des œuvres et des actions qui se déploient à travers des technologies tout en les détournant, parfois à des fins militantes :
On y trouve entre autres: un article sur le groupe d’artistes activistes californien attachés au Calit2 Lab à UCSD (University of California, San Diego) qui ont créé le Transborder Immigrant Tool, un appareil qui vise à orienter les immigrants dans le désert; une entrevue avec Constanza Camelo sur sa performance Dilater ou contracter l’univers, qui pose la question du territoire et des immigrants, projet réalisé dans le cadre de sa résidence au Studio XX et, en regard de la production des médias locatifs, un compte-rendu du jeu The Haunting, qui prend comme lieu d’investigation le Mont-Royal, issu du groupe de recherche the Mobile Digital Commons Network (MDCN).
Et puis, pour accompagner vos ballades estivales avec lègèreté, .dpi vous offre deux Flip Books à télécharger sur Ipod, conçus par l’artiste Natacha Clitandre.

bodyenglish: This year, Art's Birthday is organic! And, our Art is digital and opaque, created in the image of the choices we have made in our networked lives.On January 17th, 2008 ...that's tomorrow!...  Studio XX welcomes artist Pascale Malaterre and her guests to its website - Olfa Driss, Alexandra Cloutier, Karin Combi - for Art's Birthday!Website, texts, images and video clip Happy Art's Birthday 2008! Art's Birthday is an annual event first proposed in 1963 by French Fluxus artist Robert Filliou. He suggested that 1,000,000 years ago, there was no art. But one day, on the 17th of January to be precise, Art was born. According to Filliou, it happened when someone dropped a dry sponge into a bucket of water. Art was thus born and artists and artist groups worldwide celebrate this important anniversary by organizing international events and network art happenings, and by eating cake and offering gifts to Art. Every year, Art's Birthday becomes an occasion for exchange between artists and art events. The Eternal Network grows this way by exploring the telecommunications arts.
bodyfrench: Cette année la fête de l'art est bio !!!!! et notre art, numérique et opaque, à l'image de nos choix de vie en réseau.Le 17 janvier 2008, le Studio XX accueille sur son site Web l'artiste Pascale Malaterre et ses invités - Olfa Driss, Alexandra Cloutier, Karin Combi - pour la fête de l'art!Site Web avec textes,images et vidéo Bonne fête de l'art 2008! Depuis la proclamation de l'artiste Fluxus Robert Filliou, en 1963, le 17 janvier est la Fête de l'Art. Il proposait que l'art est né il y a environ 1,000,000 d'années quand quelqu’un s'empara d'une éponge et la plongea dans un seau d'eau. Depuis ce temps, les artistes et groupes d'artistes partout sur la planète s'activent à célébrer cet anniversaire en organisant des événements internationaux et des happenings en réseau, en mangeant du gâteau et en offrant des cadeaux à l'Art. À chaque année, la Fête de l'Art devient une occasion d'échange entre artistes et entre événements. La « Fête Permanente » s'agrandit ainsi d'année en année tout en explorant les arts des télécommunications.
